intro: Cerothamnus inodorus, commonly known as the New Zealand flax, is a shrub native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Plantaginaceae and is characterized by its dense, fibrous leaves that are used for traditional weaving. The plant typically grows in coastal and lowland areas, thriving in moist, well-drained soils. It produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are usually green or white in color. Due to its ecological and cultural significance, it is often cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
